awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Refreezing in the firn of the Greenland ice sheet: Spatiotemporal variability and implications for ice sheet mass balance
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is warming and the Greenland ice sheet is melting.  In total, the ice sheet stores enough water to raise sea level by approximately 6 meters.  However, how surface meltwater generated in the summer makes its way from its location on the ice sheet to the ocean is not well understood.  Two competing but not mutually exclusive theories are 1) the meltwater percolates into the ice sheet pores and is stored for a relatively long time.  2) The initial infiltrating meltwater refreezes at shallow depth in the firm, forming a hard pan that prohibits further infiltration.  In this latter case, the meltwater quickly moves downslope along the surface of the ice sheet until it drains into the ocean.  Rennermalm will test these hypotheses through a combination of field work, remote sensing from satellites, and modeling.  Moreover, Rennermalm believes that during the most recent warming, the shallow refreezing mechanism has been playing a lesser role in the delivery of meltwater to the ocean than in previous times. To explore this hypothesis Rennermalm will compare the physical characteristics of modern cores with those extracted from earlier expeditions.

The project will involve graduate and undergraduate student training.  The PI?s will collaborate with the Rutgers Film Bureau to ensure effective communication with the public.  The PI?s expect that the Rutgers Film Bureau director will seek to showcase the documentary at film festivals and other venues. In year one, two Rutgers Film Bureau members (the director and one student) will travel to Greenland to capture the day-to-day choices of scientific research in an extreme environment and produce a short multimedia narrative. 

Sea level is expected to rise in the decades to come, partially due to the melting of the Greenland ice sheet.  However, we do not fully understand how meltwater generated on the surface of the ice sheet makes its way to the ocean.  One line of thinking is that surface meltwater makes its way into the porous ice sheet where it is stored, either refrozen or in a liquid state, for relatively long times.  Alternatively, as proposed by these investigators, the first seasonal meltwater that makes its way into the shallow ice, refreezes and blocks further infiltration, resulting in water that quickly moves down the surface ice sheet until it enters the ocean.  Knowing the fate of meltwater is imperative if we are to understand how fast sea level will rise in the future.  These investigators will integrate field work, computer modeling, and analyze data from satellites.

por.por_cntn:
Melting of the Greenland ice sheet is one of the main causes of current sea-level rise. Most of the meltwater originates close to the margin of the ice sheet. Here, water runs along the impermeable ice surface or through tunnels in the ice ending up directly into the sea. At higher elevations, where not all winter snow melts away during summer, meltwater infiltrates into the porous firn (old snow) and refreezes. Firn can extend several tens of meters below the surface and therefore theoretically absorb vast amounts of meltwater. However, following the extreme melt year of 2012, scientists discovered unusually thick ice layers close to the firn surface. These ice layers may have prevent meltwater from infiltrating deeper into older firn layers and instead, this meltwater may run off the ice sheet. Hence the presence of these thick ice layers affect the fate of the melt water and thus the mass budget of the entire ice sheet.

To investigate these processes, we collected 24 new shallow firn cores (up to 20 m deep) at several sites in southwest Greenland between 2017-2019. We found thicker and more ice layers at lower elevations, and at one location thicker ice layers in 2017 than in a core drilled in 1989. However, we also discovered that after the extreme melt year of 2012, when thick ice layers formed, new snow layers accumulated on top of the ice layers, especially at higher elevations. As a result more melt water was able to refreeze in the following years, instead of running off the ice sheet and contributing to sea-level rise. We also calculated the energy available for melt using observations from weather stations. We found that calculating the amount of melt using weather station data is challenging in an environment where summer air temperatures are very close to the freezing point. These challenges may be problematic for Regional Climate Models as well. Comparison with observations show that these models tend to overestimate air temperatures at higher elevations on the ice sheet.

Satellite images showed large areas of fully water-saturated snow. The extent of these areas varies strongly from year to year and throughout the melt season following trends in air temperature. These so-called blue-slush areas appear preferentially in areas where the surface is very flat, and where ice layers tend to be thicker. Hence water pools on top of the ice layers, allowing the snow to become fully saturated.

Our ice core and meteorological data are archived at a publicly available data center and will be valuable for other studies and comparisons to future similar data sets as the Greenland ice sheet continues to be affected by climate change. This project provided training and professional development for two undergraduate students and three graduate students. Finally, Utuqaq, A 27-minute film about the fieldwork in 2018 was created by filmmaker Iva Radivojević and is freely available online. This film provides a poetic portrait of scientists surveying the impacts of climate change on the Greenland ice sheet.
